text: what's up everyone drubinski here and
welcome to part four of the scariest
stories that have happened to me around
the world
[Music]
as someone who's been to 195 countries
of course there are those moments that
are really scary or dangerous that often
go undocumented or unnoticed and that's
why i'd like to make these videos to
share with you some of the more
vulnerable moments that i have as a
traveler and i think a lot of you guys
want to hear these things and a lot of
you guys can relate to some of these
stories so we're going to kick it off
right away with something that happened
to me in the libyan airport
let's start off by getting the visa into
libya because it was the most expensive
visa i've ever had to get and it was
also a nightmare i was traveling around
africa on a big trip in 2019 and then i
ended in syria and then in order to get
the libya visa i had to either fly to
new york to the embassy or go to rome to
the libyan embassy in rome so obviously
rome was closer so i flew to rome for a
full week and i waited to get the visa
which i paid extra to expedite and i had
to stay in rome and i had to keep
renewing my hotel every night because i
wasn't sure when the visa was going to
be done the people working at the
embassy were not friendly and it was
very very difficult and challenging it
ended up costing 3 000
total to get the libyan visa if you
factor in the flight to rome the hotels
that i had to buy in rome and the cost
of the visa itself which is crazy also i
should have mentioned that in order to
get a visa to libya you have to be on a
business visa because i don't issue
tourist visas that means i had to
pretend to be an oil consultant because
that was what we wrote on the
application and literally once again
that's the only way to get into libya
and in order to get the business visa
you have to be on a business trip so i
had to buy some nice clothes i had to
get a briefcase and had to leave my bags
behind in tunisia which was a pretty
interesting experience to say the least
so i go to the airport i board my flight
and i get into tripoli actually the
airport was about three hours east of
tripoli because the tripoli airport was
not functioning and so i get on the
plane i arrive and i'm really nervous of
course and i go through customs and i go
through immigration and they ask me some
questions like who are you what's your
name what are you doing here so i just
answered i'm an oil consultant and then
they said go to the other room and i was
like oh great here we go you never want
to get that call go into the other room
they ask you for more questioning and
it's uh it gets pretty scary and and as
i'm telling these stories i'm i'm
reminded of how anxious i was in these
situations by the way i'm not stamped
into the country yet this is like before
he stamped me he told me to go to the
other room so i walk through and i'm
sitting in this little tiny room about
half the size of the room i'm in now i
sit down and there's two libyan guards
like standing there looking at me with
pretty intense eyes they speak very
broken english and my arabic is even
more broken i can speak maybe 20 phrases
in arabic so they asked me what i'm
doing there and i said i'm an oil
consulted and i'm here for a project and
they said what's the name of your
company and i didn't have a business
card or anything so i just said oh i'm
self-employed like i'm um i'm a solo
consultant which i mean i guess that's
possible um and they really didn't
believe me and so we were stuck in the
room for maybe 10 minutes which felt
like an hour and i'm like starting to
sweat and i my phone's not working
because there's no signal there and i
couldn't even take out my phone i wasn't
in a good
situation to do that and
i did have my camera my uh bigger dslr
camera in my bag which i was told not to
bring and so thankfully that didn't go
through my bags if they did it would
have been a huge nightmare and i didn't
have my drone a drone would have sent me
to prison so i'm standing there and um
i'm like literally scared i don't know
what to do i'm trying to convince these
guys that i'm a good person that i can
come into libya and um they're not
really budging it and all of a sudden as
they're talking amongst each other
they're kind of murmuring and i'm just
standing there like they're looking
through my passport oh why do you have
syria visa why do you have egypt visa
why do you have turkmenistan and then
you can see their eyebrows like popping
and while we're sitting there all of a
sudden i hear this
literally sounded like a machine gun my
reaction was freak out so i jumped out
of my seat i grabbed my bag and i bolted
out the door and i started running and
everybody else heard it and they were
kind of alarmed but they weren't like
they weren't freaking out as if like
there was a shooter inside the airport
like like i thought so i get down the
hall a little bit and then the guys the
police officers come out kind of with a
smile on a half smile on their face and
they're like come back come back i was
like what happened there's a there's a
shooter what are you crazy and they do
this like so apparently someone had lit
fireworks right outside the airport i
mean we're talking like right outside
the building which
who does that like who lights fireworks
right outside the airport and so that
was what the sound of of what i thought
was gunshots was that was like one of
the most scared i've ever been in my
whole life like sitting in that back
room with the libyan officials and
thinking that there's a shooter in the
airport i like i was like i thought like
okay my life's gone this is crazy so go
back in the room sit down i mean i'm
like all fired up and and it almost like
calmed them down a little bit and then
finally thankfully i had the number of
the driver that was going to pick me up
and i had his name i think it was
muhammad and so they were able to call
muhammad and muhammad knew to tell them
in case they called that i'm an oil
consultant and i'm going to be there on
a business trip just for three days and
i'm staying in tripoli which they
believed they escorted me back to
immigration stamped my passport and then
they walked me out of the airport and
when i got outside that airport and i
smelled the not so fresh air the hot
humid air of libya i was so happy
because i knew that that was one of the
hardest countries in the world to visit
what's up libya country number 184
man that's
scary yeah that was like the most scared
i've ever been in an airport
they were questioning us what's our job
we were like oil consultant they said
what company i said oh we work for
ourselves and they didn't believe it so
then i had to call the driver who's
right in front of me
we made it
oh god
we made it and in the end it turned out
to be incredible we visited a place
called leptus magna which is an old
roman ruined town it's just so beautiful
and then in tripoli is just like this
really
awe-inspiring italian influence from the
italian colonization and the food is
great and it's just there's all these
old roman ruins in town and there's a
beautiful old square and a market and
it's just really really cool so that is
uh the crazy story i wanted to share
with you from libya
for the next story we're going to hop
over to a town in iraq called chebaish
i was there one of my more recent trips
it was about eight months ago i was in
iraq with my buddy alvarado we were road
tripping solo we had a driver
and we were in the marshlands because in
southern iraq and southern iran there's
these marshlands they're called the
mesopotamian marshlands it's the unesco
world heritage site for its beauty and
there's these marsh arabs that are
living on the water on the wetlands and
the only way to get from point a to
point b is by boat it's a really unique
wetland ecosystem in the middle of a
really hot desert so we went down and
the town is called chabaish which is
like the nearest entry point into the
marshlands and i made a video about this
place which i'll link right there and
it's a really really amazing story we go
we have our experience on the marshlands
it's great everything's fine and dandy
we meet some cool people we ate muscov
which is a local freshwater fish and it
was really a wonderful experience when
we got back into the town i found myself
walking through the market trying to you
know shoot a little 10 video and try to
get some budget travel stuff going on
and just get some good content really
because it was such a unique part of
iraq alvaro stayed behind in the car he
did not join i was with another local
friend named hussein he was a little bit
away from me like 50 feet away from me
and i was shooting on my gopro so i
didn't think it'd be an issue and i held
it on my chest because i wanted to keep
keep it like away from people so i'm
shooting i'm recording i'm going to the
market and all of a sudden
someone grabs my arm like this and i'm
like i look over i thought it was my
friend it was the police i'd been
shooting in baghdad i've been sh i'd
been shooting in samara and some other
you know places karbala najaf and i
didn't have issues with the police in
public and i thought oh this is like the
safest part of iraq this would be fine
it was not cool with them it ended up
being a huge ordeal um first of all they
asked where my friend was and i had to
like flag him down so that was scary and
then my friend starts talking to him and
they're like oh what what happened why
is he filming who's this guy why is he
here and i was like freaking out i
stepped aside like what do i do as soon
as i said it's super safe here we got
busted by the police i didn't have my
passport on me also my passport was left
in the car slowly i went behind the
scenes and i kind of went in my phone
and i deleted a bunch of pictures
because they don't like to have pictures
for whatever reason and so then they
start dragging me to the police station
by myself my friend is left behind in
the market he was actually went back to
the car to try to find alvaro and our
driver and so then i'm left there again
with the police and they start walking
me to the police station and that's a
place that you don't want to go in iraq
you don't want to go to a police station
anywhere in the world especially in iraq
when you don't have a passport on you
and my phone was working i had a sim
card but
it wasn't working that well because the
town is very remote and it wasn't like a
big city so i'm in the police station my
friend catches up to me finally and
we're in the back room and i'm just he
asked for my passport and i'm like i
don't have my passport but i'm spanish
because alvaro was spanish even though
he wasn't with me at the moment but
every time you say your spanish they get
excited because they talk about
barcelona or madrid football team and
and i know nothing about soccer but i do
speak spanish and so i was able to ablar
um espanol and i spoke to the people and
and the security police and then they
thought i was spanish and sure enough
they had a little joke that i was from
spain and they love football and they're
naming all these players and i'm like
okay whatever it's still really scary to
be in a freaking police station they
like when they open the gate to the
compound you hear this like creaky sound
and i'm just like who's gonna come here
the biggest risk is being kidnapped you
know the police just has to call one
friend
and be like hey we got an america i
guess a spanish person here uh he's
probably got a lot of money on him and
he probably has a lot of equipment so
let's rob him let's kidnap him and
that's that was my biggest fear uh turns
out you know the police ended up being
nice people in the end and they did let
me go they did check my phone and
thankfully i deleted a lot of those
photos and videos that i took and at the
end they were just like you need to be
careful what you're shooting don't put
the camera in anyone's face which i
wasn't doing i was shooting general
shots of the market but uh lesson
learned be careful in iraq and always
have your passport on you because that's
really really really really important so
uh yeah iraq was an amazing country i
think you guys have seen i hope you've
seen my videos there
i've made over 10 videos in iraq and
just a wonderful country filled with
beautiful architecture smiles everywhere
and it's just a really humble culture
and delicious food as well so that is my
story about iraq
third and final scary story i'm going to
share with you today is a general travel
story to mogadishu somalia right off the
bat mogadishu is the most dangerous city
in the world somalia is not the most
dangerous country it's one of the most
but in terms of cities mogadishu they've
been in constant civil war since 1991
the year i was born constant there
hasn't been a single break there's been
a lot of different offshoot al-qaeda
isis terrorist groups
all over the place al-shabab is the name
of one of them and uh it's it's very
unstable there's kidnappings bombings
gun violence all kinds of explosions and
terrorist attacks and and it's it's
unfortunately that's the case of
mogadishu and i knew that going in and
so i met my good friend liabimonti he
flew from the u.s and he met me and we
jumped on a plane from arizaba ethiopia
and we got into
mogadishu somalia so our buddy bashar
joined us he's a somali guy but he lives
in juba south sudan he was my local
friend there and he was able to help us
get the visa which is also hard to get
so we arrive at the airport and you have
to go through like a maze to get out of
the airport it's there's dogs everywhere
like canines sniffing dogs and
people looking at you and it's just
crazy we get in this taxi and they said
the hotel is one mile away it's called
peace hotel ironically and so i'm like
oh cool one mile i'll be like two minute
drive right took about 25 minutes to get
there because there's so many
checkpoints from the airport to the
hotel checkpoints they'll just stop you
the military will be like who are you
who are you going the windows in our car
are bulletproof and they're blacked out
so nobody can see inside and then
there's all these like barricades and
then we finally get to the main gate of
the hotel and you check in and they have
our name on a list and then literally
you have to drive like this then you
turn and you drive like that
then you hit the dead end and you turn
like that and like that and then you
make another turn and then they lift up
a gate and you go through the gate and
then you go down and up and then left
turn again right turn again and finally
you get to a door then you get your bags
out go to the door you take off your
shoes it's like the airport take up
shoes empty out your bag and believe me
they empty out your bag check everything
on you ask you questions then you get
into the main compound of the hotel then
you go check in and this amazing guy he
greeted us the first thing he did was
he's like all right we need to give you
a safety briefing and we'll be like all
right
so we go downstairs in like a bunker
this is like straight out of a movie
like this room that we entered and
remember we are in somalia okay we open
up this door and there's all these giant
screens i felt like i was in a
simulation with all these massive
screens and there must have been at
least ten thousand dollars worth of
equipment down there it was wild so he
goes and sits in his chair opens his
computer which is how he's controlling
everything and he opens up this massive
map of the city i mean it probably takes
up my whole wall behind me right
and
it's mogadishu and there's all these
little red flags everywhere there must
have been 100 red flags okay he looks at
us and he says see all those red flags
those are all the bombings and terrorist
attacks that have happened in mogadishu
over the last few years he also had
cameras set up around the whole city
with live footage of what was happening
in all the main squares and everything
this guy
knows
safety he knows he has all the
connections and i was just like
mind blown by the system that he had
created for security i mean it was it
was unbelievable so he spent about an
hour explaining to us where we're going
to go and what we had to do and and why
we had to stay safe and all this stuff
and so we went to bed and we woke up the
next morning and we were going to go see
some sites in issue right the two trucks
pickup trucks pick us up and
we are in a jeep with bulletproof
everything windows doors and blacked out
windows okay and in the front of us is a
pickup truck with four armed guards with
like bulletproof vest helmets on and
huge guns ak-47s or similar four guys
sitting on the pickup truck in front of
us and they're both in each corner of
the bed of the truck behind us four more
guys all decked out in gear guns finger
on trigger in hand so we have eight
military guys fully loaded ready for
combat and we're driving through the
streets of mogadishu with all this crazy
security and so i'm like biting my nails
in the back of the seat like other car
and i'm like what is going on i hope
we're gonna be safe we went to this
lighthouse
and they dropped us off and we pulled up
we stopped and then they said okay wait
five minutes we gotta do a scout of the
location and so all the eight military
guys jumped out the car and like i
watched them from the window they would
like literally peek over the fence look
through everything go under places and
like just scout out the whole area like
full on scouting out it was wild then
they're like okay you have 10 minutes
only go walk on the beach and go look at
the lighthouse take your pictures and
we're out so we're like okay so i'm like
what like in all the background of my
gopro shots my videos in mogadishu the
guys are there it's it's like it's wild
so we're going around taking our
pictures and then they're like okay you
got everything go back in the car
so that's how we went around mogadishu
it is crazy we went to an ice cream
place where i met my buddy dan what's up
dan um and we got ice cream together we
hung out and then i found out a few
months later that that whole place was
shot up and like 20 people or so were
killed in that ice cream place so
mogadishu is just crazy you always got
to be on your toes you got to be
expecting something and you just got to
be careful for if something goes wrong
here's what here's how i'm going to
react here's how i'm going to prepare
myself
of course we don't want any of that to
happen
i think somali culture is beautiful i
love somaliland i love the food and the
people are so friendly but mogadishu
really truly is the world's most
dangerous city and i'm just glad that i
made it out safely what a crazy
experience thank you guys for tuning in
you know i like talking about these
things and i feel like a lot of you guys
like to hear it because as much as i
love to go to the middle east and go to
asia and sit on the floor and eat with
my hands and share with you how
hospitable these people are and show you
the wonders of the world i think it's
important to not ignore some of the
dangerous parts about this lifestyle and
i want to be transparent with you guys
and let you know what life is really
like to visit every country so with that
being said
thank you for watching i will see you
guys in the next video have a great day
and take care bye
